clean_content:
Definition / general

* Pathological enlargement of lymph nodes caused by abnormal accumulation of fat, due to mature, benign adipocytes within lymph node capsules

Sites

* Most commonly involved sites are external iliac and obturator groups

Pathophysiology

* Accumulation of abnormal quantities of fat within lymph nodes in excess of normal aging changes* Benign process with good prognosis* Can cause mass effect depending on size* May mimic lymphoma or other neoplasms

Etiology

* Unknown; postulated causes include exaggeration of normal fat deposition with aging, previous abdominal inflammatory disease, obesity

Clinical features

* Enlarged lymph nodes; may lead to formation of large masses up to 10 cm

Radiology description

* Progressive enlargement and increased fatty infiltration* CAT scan and lymphangiography findings can be misleading towards neoplastic process

Case reports

* 47 year old man with abundant macroscopic fat in intra-abdominal lymph nodes ([Br J Radiol 2012;85:e91](22457415))* 49 year old woman with lipoplastic lymphadenopathy presenting as an ovarian mass ([Gynecol Oncol 1987;28:345](3678982))* 50 year old man with generalized lipomatosis of lymph nodes ([Lymphology 1979;12:262](529830))* Middle aged women with lipolymph nodes of mesentery ([Am Surg 1985;51:596](4051336))* Lipoplastic lymphadenopathy simulating lymphoma and pelvic lipomatosis ([J Urol 1975;114:788](1185883))* Pelvic and aortic lipolymph nodes ([Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand 1982;61:383](7148416))

Treatment

* Excision of involved lymph node in symptomatic cases serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes

Clinical images

*Images hosted on other servers:*  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesadiposetissuemetaplasiathumbimg01.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3486662/figure/bjr-85-e091-g002/)

Progressively enlarging lymph node

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/lymphnodesadiposetissuemetaplasiathumbimg02.jpg)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3486662/figure/bjr-85-e091-g001/)

Largest intra-abdominal adenopathy

Gross description

* Enlarged lymph node with soft greasy yellow areas within capsule, or entirely replaced by similar cut surfaces

Gross images

Contributed by Jayalakshmi Balakrishna, M.D.
  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesadiposetissuemetaplasia_Balakrishna01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesadiposetissuemetaplasia_Balakrishna01.jpg)

Lymph node replaced by adipose tissue

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Benign mature adipocytes populate nodes whose capsules are thinly attenuated with fine vascular trabeculae dividing fat deposits

Microscopic (histologic) images

Lymphoid tissue closely admixed with adipocytes

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesadiposetissuemetaplasia_Balakrishna04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/lymphnodesadiposetissuemetaplasia_Balakrishna04.jpg)

Lymph node with adipocytes within capsule

Differential diagnosis

* Intranodal [angiolipoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/softtissueadiposeangiolipoma.html) ([Int J Surg Pathol 2005;13:99](15735863))* Other causes of lymphadenopathy: lymphoma, metastases, inflammatory / infectious causes* Retroperitoneal or [pelvic lipomatosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/softtissueadiposelipomatosis.html)

Additional references

* [Rosai and Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 10th Edition, 2011](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/032306969X/pathologyoutl-20)
